python.message: Infinite loops like 'while True' can be dangerous. Consider checking a specific condition instead.
A bare 'except:' catches all errors, including system exits. It's better to catch specific exceptions like 'except ValueError:'.
Comparisons to None should verify identity, not equality. Use 'if x is None:' instead.
Error Prevention: When opening files, use the 'with open(...)' style. This acts as a Context Manager that ensures the file closes automatically, even if your code crashes.
Best Practice: Avoid verifying types with 'type(x) =='. Use 'isinstance(x, class)' instead, as it correctly handles inheritance.
Warning: Do not use 'assert' for critical logic. It can be disabled by Python optimization flags. Use standard if-statements and raise Exceptions instead.

cpp.message: Best Practice: Using 'namespace std' globally can cause naming conflicts in larger projects. It is safer to use 'std::cout' or specific using declarations.
Style: The 'goto' statement makes code execution hard to follow (spaghetti code). Try rewriting logic using loops or functions.
Error Prevention: In C++, 'new' is preferred over 'malloc' because it ensures Class constructors are called properly.
Best Practice: Consider using 'const' or 'constexpr' variables instead of macros. Macros ignore scope rules and can cause confusing bugs.
Syntax Error: 'void main' is non-standard C++. The main function must always return an integer. Use 'int main' and return 0.
Best Practice: In modern C++ (C++11+), use 'nullptr' instead of 'NULL'. It is type-safe and prevents accidental conversion to integers.
Performance: Using 'std::endl' forces the output buffer to flush every time, which is very slow in loops. Use '\n' for a new line instead.
